item.description:
The Harvard Food Literacy Project is presenting TUPPERWARE! as part of its summer lunchtime film series. It is free and open to the public.

I just couldn't resist this one: I actually own some Tupperware (that certifies my Nerd status right there). ﻿Think of this movie as a bit of Americana, a bit of American history, a little bit about women's rights. Tupperware was invented in Leominster, Massachusetts, in 1946, part of the postwar consumer boom. The woman who made it and its marketing technique famous was Brownie Wise. Her first job was selling Stanley Home Products, once headquartered in Westfield, Massachusetts; one of the Stanley Home Products divisions is still located there. (The pond on the company's grounds was once home to a pair of attack-swans, but that's another story.)

Here's what the Harvard Food Literacy Project had to say about TUPPERWARE! via e-mail:

*****TUPPERWARE! takes us back to the 1950s where we discover the remarkable story of a woman who's been erased from history and meet the women she taught to move up in the world without leaving their homes. Rare archival footage and fabulously funny stories are interwoven in the thought-provoking tale of Brownie Wise, the self-taught saleswoman who built an empire out of bowls that burped. Featured in magazines and newspapers, she was the first woman ever on the cover of Business Week. Yet no one knows her name. TUPPERWARE! traces the dramatic story of Brownie Wise's rise from a hardscrabble Southern childhood to her spectacular fall in the glare of the national press. 63 minutes.

All films will be screened on Fridays at lunchtime (12 noon to 1 p.m.) in Dana Palmer House (16 Quincy Street), Room 102. Bring your lunch. Appropriately themed snacks will be provided.*****

I have no idea what "appropriately themed snacks" means for a movie about Tupperware. You can bring your lunch to this movie, or we can go out in Harvard Square after the movie if that's what people would like to do. The movie is just over one hour long.

Because I have never been to the Dana Palmer House or to a movie event hosted by the Harvard Food Literacy project, I will make sure to arrive early. My plan is to arrive between 11:30 and 11:45 a.m. I'll be carrying my bright red backpack and a meetup sign. (If you want to talk to other people carrying bright red backpacks but no meetup sign, that's perfectly fine!)

Look for me after the movie. I'll try to gather everyone, and then we can decide if we would like to go out for something in Harvard Square.

See you at the Dana Palmer House!

Marianne
item.how_to_find_us: Look for my bright red backpack *and* my meetup sign. See the event description for more details.
